comments.commentBody:
I think Abner Mikva was much better known as a four-term maverick Democratic congressman from Chicago (whom both parties tried to gerrymander out of office) and then for 15 years as a judge of the U.S District Court for D.C. than he was as Clinton's counsel.

Laszlo—It's hard to believe you've never heard of the controversial company that Mitt Romney ran and made a fortune from. You must have some mystical ability to tune out network news reports and presidential campaign ads.

Economic and Physical Stress: leads to self medication with booze, drugs both legal and illegal, poor health habits like smoking, risky behaviors, lack of self care, abuse  any surprise these people are dying young than their wealthier peers?  Not really do we need a learned 'study' to know this?

I don't really care about "easy" or "hard," which is of course subjective and also dependent on the solver's area(s) of knowledge. What I look for is challenge in solving, learning perhaps new words or usages, and clever and amusing cluing.

I don't solve for time--I'm not in a competition, even with myself--and am usually doing something else like eating or cuddling a cat or watching the TV news while I do the puzzle.

I think there are four ranges of difficulty. First, I solve on my own with maybe a Google or two. Second, I need to read Deb's article to solve. Third, I need to scan the rest of the blog. And, finally, there are the ones I can't finish at all. No math required.
Take any ten people and you'll probably end up with sixteen ways to classifying "easy" to "hard".

It is interesting to read comments suggesting a particular puzzle is relatively hard or easy. There is that subjective sense, but also how long does it take to complete or how many errors are made. Each day there is variation in difficulty, potentially measured by average time across many solvers, as well as the increase in difficulty between Monday and Saturday. There is also the fact that each solver has good days and bad days, or even variation depending upon time of day, fatigue, etc. The only way to determine how hard or easy a given puzzle is would be to measure the average time to solve it compared to other puzzles solved by the same group and see if it is more than 1.5 or 2.0 standard deviations from the mean.

Sarah

"It is all legal.". What do you base that on? Do we know whether or not the IRS ever challenged any of his loopholes? It is possible that embedded in that 20 year average are some years in which he paid zero in federal taxes and some years in which he had to pay back taxes with penalties for improper deductions. Mr. Romney says that he has paid all that is legally owed. That could include all penalties as well. We just don't know.

Mr. Romney may be a successful business man and a giving human being but that doesn't mean that he is the best person to reform the tax code by closing loopholes, After all he had probably taken advantage of many legal but inefficient loopholes himself. Now, if he wants to be taken seriously about tax code reform, he could explain some of the loopholes that he has used in the past and serve no purpose other than to reward a lucky few who have great legislative contacts. And after explaining them, he could recommend closing them.

Tsultrim - the Veterans Job Corp Act was halted by 40 GOP Senators - http://www.politicususa.com/meet-40-senate-republicans-betrayed-veterans... The only Republican Senators who voted for it were Sens. Scott Brown (MA), Susan Collins (ME), Dean Heller (NV), Lisa Murkowski (AK) and Olympia Snowe (ME). Two GOP Senators - James Inhofe (OK) and Mark Kirk (IL) - didn't vote.
Martin, does that mean only Sunday through Friday are "some" days, and Saturday is "another" day?

C,mon, you two guys, Let's not be Petty...it's not pretty, infact, it tends to IRK-some of us!

Allow me to ADHERE...somewhere EN LAIs the truth...

I own three watches, my SACCO is my favorite...
I'm so Bulova it!

Howie
YEO-ho-ho and a bottle of rum.

A petty officer in the U.S. Navy is the equivalent of the Army’s noncommissioned officer: an enlisted man authorized to issue orders to subordinates. A Navy yeoman is an enlisted man with administrative or clerical duties, i.e. not a noncommissioned officer; to put it another way, “yeoman” is a job description (in naval jargon, a “rating”). Cf. “U.S.N. clerk: Abbr.” = YEO (1/15/09).

I'd love to see someone actually and officially investigate Ann Coulter's questionable voting habits...

In 2004, I believe, its known she registered at an address in Florida which was in fact her agent's address (she later claimed she did it because voter registration records, complete with addresses, are public records, and she needed her privacy). As a result, she voted illegally from a different address than where she was registered. When this became public, the GOP county DA and the GOP State Attorney-General refused to even look into the allegations.
Then in, I believe, 2002, it was discovered she was registered simultaneously in both Florida and New York. Its not known in which state she actually voted, but True-The-Vote groups often whine about people registered to vote in multiple states, as if this were criminal. Of course, it doesn't indicate anyone ever voted more than once, just that they may have voted in the wrong district (which really only matters as a rule for local/state elections, not Presidential voting).

They define decency differently than normal human beings do.  They see it as wearing designer clothes and driving an expensive six or seven cars.  They don't equate decency with kind regard or respect for others.  That isn't something others deserve.  Just sayin'.

Brian, my favorite is the Texas Voter Disenfranchisement Law. They don't have a specific voter ID, but instead a list of what ID's are acceptable. Ideally, one would think a state issued photo ID is the best, right? And its true a driver's license is acceptable...but if you don't have a driver's license, but do have a state-issued photo ID given to students at the University of Texas, well, sorry! The GOP-run state government has decided that is NOT an acceptable ID!
But if you happen to be an NRA member, and show your non-state-issued, no photo-ID NRA membership card? Yes, right this way to the voting booth!!
The rich can afford lawyers and sue for harassment.
I'vebeen a registered voter for many years and have voted legally in several Massachusetts towns and cities. I have never received a voter registration card.

Many of us down here feel the same way.  But yet about half of the voters will continue to vote the way they have for many years.  There is no explanation for it.  Maybe they think they'll win the lottery, but as far as Obama goes I think it's just pure racism.

We've seen for nearly a decade what sort of government the republicans favor.  They are desperate, have been for over a decade, probably 3 decades, and are willing to try anything to win.  Any political party that has to lie and cheat to win surely doesn't belong in America but the gop has sure made that acceptable today.
NO, none at all.  Any decent republicans have been replaced.

People, it's all about power and control.  Really.  Those that want it will say and do anything to get it.  Voter suppression is as good a tool as any.  So is money.  Romney, the Koch brothers, Sheldon Adelson – they've made their money.  Now they want power.

Good question.  It would depend on the state, but depending on the service they need, one form of id would be their social security card.  Some poor people and elderly do not rely on any social services.

In Australia, a democracy and true friend to the USA, one is REQUIRED to vote. Sounds good to me. I know this is antithetical to our idea of a free society (i.e. free not to participate, but gain all benefits), but it's worth thinking about.

Everyione gets a voter card and is in the roll when he or she arrives at the polls. Then you have to sign. THAT SHOULD BE ENOUGH. To heck with these racist, exclusivist, repressive laws! Their proponents have admitted publicly (e.g. speaker of the PA House) that these laws favor Republicans. Self identified Republicans are less than a third of the electorate. No wonder they are desperate.
The gop has had to do this for quite some time.  If they played fair and honest they would not win very many elections at most any level.
Bill Koch is also trying to buy a town and make it a wild west disneyland. See the September 10th New Yorker.

I envy those who still can vote in person. Yes, the harassment exists at the polls, but for those of us living in mail only States, the possibilities  of voter fraud are real. Who can tell if the elderly actually vote their own ballots? Who polices  coercive mass voting at fundamentalist churches etc?
There is a fair way to vote, and it is the one that exists NOW. If you were required to show ID everywhere you went there would be zero financial fraud too. You are advocating Stalinism.

Except for the New Black Panthers were at a majority black precinct.  Do you really think they were there to keep people from voting?  They were there because they've heard about or have seen vote suppression tactics like those described here, internalized them, and became paranoid to an unhealthy degree.  They thought they were trying to PREVENT voter intimidation, not commit it.

or...perhaps Charles W. woulld like to expand on his opinion that the Democratice Party would approve of voter suppression of Republican voters, that is the 33% of likely voters so identified.

So Charles, what say you?

And of that amount, they were OBLIGED to give a 10% donation to their church to be “in good standing.”  Without maintaining good standing they would be excluded from entering LDS temples, for example.
Correction Mr. Ryan - they gave a per centage of their adjusted gross income.
